title: Buckingham Railway Walk Route

images.title: mick finn / Old Railway Bridge, Bath Lane
images.caption: Old Railway Bridge, Bath Lane. The old railway bridge over Bath Lane, Buckingham. There is now a footpath where once the trains rolled.

images.title: al partington / The Mitre, Buckingham
images.caption: The Mitre, Buckingham. Three to four changing beers from all parts of the country in this cosy pub adjacent to the old railway viaduct. The thatched building in the foreground is Mitre Cottage - the remains of a 15 century cruck framed hall house converted in the 17th century when a 1st floor was added.

images.title: mick finn / Weir on the Ouse
images.caption: A weir on the river Ouse alongside Station Rd, Buckingham.

images.title: Mark R Dornan / The 'Flosh' & Lords Bridge, Buckingham
images.caption: The 'Flosh' & Lords Bridge, Buckingham. This weir on the river Ouse is related to Town Mill. The road crossing the Lords Bridge is Hunter St. which leads to the 'prebend end beyond the water'. The weir and mill now fall within Buckingham University's Hunter Street campus.

images.title: Maddie Hooper / Pond in Railway Walk, Buckingham
images.caption: Pond in Railway Walk, Buckingham

images.title: Maddie Hooper / Signpost, Railway Walk, Buckingham
images.caption: Signpost, Railway Walk, Buckingham

images.title: Fractal Angel / Railway cutting
images.caption: Railway cutting Looking SE from the site of the former bridge under Tingewick Road. Buckingham was a station on the London & North-Western Railway branch from Verney Junction to Banbury. This section of line is now a well-kept path.

description: This easy walk follows a nice footpath along the old Buckingham railway line near the centre of Buckingham. It's a very pretty area with wildlife ponds, shady woodlands and an orchard to see. Keep your eyes peeled for a variety of flora and fauna including woodland birds, butterflies, dragonflies, amphibians and wild flowers. The walk starts just off the Tingewick Road near to the university. You can then follow the flat footpath south east to the A421. Near the start you'll pass St Rumbold's Well which is an interesting part of Buckingham's history related to the 6th century child saint. You'll also pass the River Ouse and the impressive weir at the 'Flosh' & Lords Bridge. The walk can be extended by heading north east along the Buckingham Circular Walk to Bourton Park along the Buckingham Brook.
